metadata.title: Hand Burns
anatomical location body part affected: Hand; wrist; skin (epidermis, dermis, subdermal plexus); underlying fascia, muscle, and contractile tissue; bone
description: A burn is an injury to body tissues from exposure to heat, electricity, chemicals, or radiation(1)
Hand burns account for more than 80% of severe burn cases(25)

The skin is the largest organ of the body. It consists of two layers:(4,27) –Epidermis: outermost layer, contains no blood vessels –Dermis: lies beneath the epidermis and consists of vascular connective tissue that supports and provides nutrition to the epidermis and skin appendages (e.g., hair and hair follicles, sweat glands)

The severity of burns is classified by a combination of the extent and depth of injury, as well as patient age and associated illness or injury. The extent is the percentage of total body surface area (TBSA) affected by second-  and third-degree  burns(10) –Extent (calculated based on the amount of partial and full-thickness  burns) -The arm represents 9% of TBSA, based on the “rule of nines”(a method calculating extent of the burn based on dividing the body surface area by percentages (e.g., front and back of the head an neck are 9% of the body surface area) which are then used to calculate the burned area (2) -Using the palmar surface method for small burns, the palm (not including fingers)is 0.5% of TBSA and the hand surface (palm and digits) is approximately 1%(10) –Depth: the current classification system replaces first-, second-,  and third-degree  burns and does not include fourth-degree  burns -Superficial-thickness  burn: solely affects the epidermis and usually is red, painful, warm, and may blanch when touched (e.g., sunburn)(21) -Superficial partial-thickness  burn: affects the epidermis and the superficial dermis and presents with blisters(21) -Deep partial-thickness  burn: affects the epidermis, the deep dermis, and some degree of sensory and sweat gland function; presents with less blisters and pain than superficial partial-thickness burns(21) -Full-thickness  burn: affects entire epidermal and dermal layers and results in complete loss of skin appendages; is insensate to pain(21) -Fourth-degree  burn (old classification): affects entire epidermal and dermal layers as well as underlying muscle, tendon, and bone(22)

ICD-10 codes.T23: Burn and corrosion of wrist and hand

reimbursement: Reimbursement for therapy will depend on insurance contract coverage; no specific issues or information regarding reimbursement has been identified for hand burns
presentation signs and symptoms: Based on classification:(4) –Superficial-thickness  burn: erythematous appearance, dry, mildly swollen, blanches with pressure and is painful (e.g., sunburn) –Superficial partial-thickness  burn: blistering, moist, weeping, blanches with pressure, painful –Deep partial-thickness  burn: no blisters, wet or waxy dry, variable color, less painful, at risk for conversion to full thickness due to marginal blood supply –Full-thickness  burn: white waxy to leathery grey to charred black in color, insensate to pain, does not blanch with pressure
Decreased ROM/contractures –Twenty-three  percent of patients hospitalized for a hand burn experience at least 1 contracture, with the wrist joint most frequently involved(1)

Hypertrophic scarring(4) –Hypertrophic scars can result from partial and full-thickness burns –Initially presents as a firm, red area of healed burn scar –Progresses over weeks to become raised, erythematous, and rigid

Status post amputation –For additional information on upper extremity amputation, see Clinical Reviews…Amputation, Upper Extremity, in Adults: Occupational Therapy ; CINAHL Topic ID Number: T708915, and Amputation, Upper Extremity, in Adults: Physical Therapy;  CINAHL Topic ID Number T708916
Psychosocial issues Causes, Pathogenesis, & Risk Factors
contraindications precautions to test: Stop the examination and immediately notify the referring physician if any of the following are present: –Signs/symptoms of infection(4)  –Deep vein thrombosis (DVT) –Heterotrophic ossification(4) –Joint subluxation or dislocation(24) –Compartment syndrome -Tends to occur in burns when the inelastic burned tissue (eschar) acts as a tourniquet(4) -Abdominal compartment syndrome is a potentially lethal condition in patients who are severely burned, even if abdominal decompression is performed. Significant increased abdominal pressure can cause pulmonary damage and multiorgan system failure. Only 40% of patients will survive(10) -For more information, see Clinical Review …Compartment Syndrome, Acute : CINAHL Topic ID Number: T708485 –Pneumothorax(10) –Unremitting pain
Obtain and follow specific instructions and guidelines from the referring physician and/or surgeon

As many patients report unbearable levels of pain after burn injury, it is vital to respect the patient’s pain and alert the physician and/or nurse if the patient’s pain is not being adequately controlled(4)

causes: Most common causes of all burns–Fire/flame exposure (more common in males)(4)–Scalding or heat contact injuries (more common in females)(4)

Other causes–Electrical exposure-Flash (arcing), flame, or direct heating by electrical current(10)–Contact–Chemical exposure–Tar–Radiation–Grease injuries–Up to 6%of burn injuries are the result of child abuse and are more common in males and children with developmentaldelays(4)
pathogenesis: The extent of tissue damage is related to the location, duration, and intensity (temperature) of exposure.(4) In the caseof electrical burns, skin damage does not correlate with the degree of injury. Significant subcutaneous damage can beaccompanied by little skin injury, especially in cases in which there is larger skin surface area involved due to electricalcontact(10)
Those at the extremes of age have fewer layers of epithelium, so the same exposure will produce a more serious burn inolder adults and children than in other adults(4)

The dorsum of the hand has relatively thin, supple, and mobile skin that lies in close proximity to the extensor tendons;therefore, any burns to the dorsum of the hand can result in significant functional impairment(6)

After the burn injury, there is a cascade of events(4)–Initially there is vasoconstriction at the site of the burn injury mediated by the release of norepinephrine and serotonin–A few hours after injury, vasoconstriction turns to vasodilation, increased capillary permeability, and leakage of plasmainto the extravascular space–Histamine is released and damaged cells swell–Fluid shifts result in extravascular edema and intravascular hypovolemia–Platelets and leukocytes aggregate, leading to thrombotic ischemia–In severe burn injuries, inflammatory mediators are released and compromise cardiovascular function; burn shock ensues

Damaged skin loses its ability to act as a protective barrier (4)–This may lead to loss of body fluids, impaired thermoregulation, and increased susceptibility to infection-Healing and regeneration-Because of the destruction of the dermal appendages, spontaneous reepithelialization is impossible with afull-thickness  burn injury(36)-Healing and regeneration in partial-thickness burns arise from the epithelial linings of the hair follicles and sweatglands-Depending on the depth, epithelialization is completed in 14 to 21 days-After epithelialization there is continued healing with regeneration of the peripheral nerves (sometimes withneuropathic pain and itching)-Dermal scarring occurs on the wound continuously for several months after the injury, and the healing process isongoing for 6 months to 2 years, until the skin is mature
risk factors: Most common in males in all age groups except for older adults, among whom burns occur more often in women(19)
Being a child or an older adult(18)

overall contraindications precautions: When possible, burned hands are best treated by a therapist who fully understands the unique challenges of treating burn patients (e.g., biomechanical, physical, psychological factors)(5)
Obtain parental consent before treating minors
If abuse or neglect is suspected, alert the referring physician and/or appropriate authority
Patients who have more extensive burns beyond just the hands are at risk for more complicated medical problems (e.g., shock)(4)
See specific  Contraindications/precautions to examination   and  Contraindications/precautions   under Assessment/Plan

Significant increased abdominal pressure can cause pulmonary damage and multiorgan system failure. history of present illness.mechanism of injury or etiology of illne: Mechanism of injury or etiology of illness -How and when did the burn occur? -How quickly did the patient receive medical attention? -What classification is the burn? -If not limited to just the hand(s), where and what percentage of TBSA? -Concomitant injuries (e.g., fractures, inhalation injuries, brain injury)?(7) -Approximately 5% of all trauma patients will also have some degree of burn injury(7) -If applicable, what has the treatment in the hospital involved up to this point? -Complications up to this point?

course of treatment.medical management: Medical management Management of medical complications (e.g., shock, inhalation injury); may involve resuscitation(4) Debridement(30) Mechanical Water immersion Water spray/hydro surgical (i.e., water jet) Moist to dry dressings Topical enzymes Biological debridement (i.e., sterile maggots)
surgical management: Sequential (tangential) (i.e., debride dead tissue by layer until healthy bleeding skin)
Must be replaced after several days or the immune system rejects them, and it is not common to use immunosuppressant therapy
Synthetic wound dressings are also a temporary option until autografting is possible
Harvested from the patient’s own skin
Split thickness grafts can be “meshed” to increase the area of coverage
May be useful when more coverage is needed
Groin flaps, as well as preputial flaps (in uncircumcised males), may be utilized to obtain adequate coverage
Used to immobilize fingers to protect exposed joints and tendons(5)
May be necessary in burns severe enough that circulation is absent, or bone and tissue are destroyed
course of treatment.medications: Determine what medications clinician has prescribed; are they being taken? Opioids for procedural pain(5) Long-acting  analgesics for resting pain(5) Short-acting  analgesics for breakthrough pain(5) Anxiolytics(5) Enteral feeding Tetanus immunization for all burns deeper than superficial thickness(10) Topical antibiotics for all non superficial-depth  wounds(10) Dressings Hydrogel Low adherent Silver products Adhesive Negative pressure wound therapy (e.g., wound V .A.C.)(5)
diagnostic tests completed: Diagnostic tests completed:  Usual tests for this condition are the following:
Measuring urinary output (may require indwelling catheter)(8)
Approximately 10% of burn patients will develop peripheral neuropathies, most commonly median sensory neuropathies(7)
course of treatment.alternative therapies: Document any use of home remedies (e.g., ice or heating pack) or alternative therapies (e.g., acupuncture) and whether they help
course of treatment.previous therapy: Document whether patient has had occupational or physical therapy for this or other conditions and what specific treatments were helpful or not helpful

history of present illness.aggravating easing factors: (and length of time each item is performed before the symptoms come on or are eased) there positions or environments that increase or decrease patient’s pain or itching?
history of present illness.body chart: Use body chart to document location and nature of symptoms
history of present illness.nature of symptoms: Document nature of symptoms (e.g., constant vs. intermittent, sharp, dull, aching, burning, numbness, tingling, itching)
history of present illness.rating of symptoms: Use a visual analog scale (V AS) or 010  scale to assess symptoms at their best, at their worst, and at the moment (specifically address if pain is present now and how much ). For children or nonverbal patients, the FLACC Scale or Wong-Baker  FACES Pain Rating Scale may be used to assess pain(3) -The Itch Severity Scale is a valid tool for assessing itch severity and the inability to relieve the itching sensation.(3) Another validated burn-specific  itch assessment tool is the Burn Itch Questionnaire(26)
history of present illness.pattern of symptoms: Document changes in symptoms throughout the day and night, if any (AM, mid-day, PM, night); also document changes in symptoms due to weather or other external variables
history of present illness.sleep disturbance: Document number of awakenings/night -As many as 74% of burn survivors reported sleep problems at 1 week after discharge from hospital(31)(31) -Nighttime awakenings -Daytime napping -Nighttime pain -Difficulty with sleep onset -Lack of sleep is associated with increased pain complaints the next day, and high levels of pain and analgesic intake during the day is associated with poor sleep the following night(31)
history of present illness.other symptoms: Document other symptoms patient may be experiencing that could exacerbate the condition and/or symptoms that could be indicative of a need to refer to physician (e.g., dizziness, chills, unremitting pain)
history of present illness.respiratory status: Document the patient’s respiratory status, including oxygen use and/or mechanical ventilation(7) -Pneumonia -Adult respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) -Did the patient require tracheostomy? Psychosocial status -Burn injury survivors are at risk for developing depression, anxiety, and posttraumatic stress disorders(7) -The largest prospective cohort study found that significant psychological distress is common and tends to persist for at least 2 years after burn injury(7) -Depression can have a negative impact on recovery(7) -PTSD(31) -Reported rates of PTSD in burn patients range from 20% to 69% -Development of PTSD has been associated with excessive scarring, female sex, large burn surface area, pre-existing depression, low resilience, and poor social support -Alteration in body image affecting one’s self-esteem is one of the most devastating consequences of a burn injury(7) -Individuals with altered body image report social functioning as a major source of difficulty and distress(7) -The ultimate goal of rehabilitation is normal reintegration into the community(32) -Health-related  quality of life is often negatively impacted following a burn injury, with patients with less severe injuries having less impairment in most domains. In studies of health-related  quality of life after burn injuries, scores generally improved over time, although sexual function scores commonly were stable(29) Barriers to learning -Are there any barriers to learning? past medical history.previous history of same similar diagnos: Previous history of same/similar diagnosis Is there a prior history of burn(s)? Prior history of any dysfunction involving the affected hand(s)?
past medical history.comorbid diagnoses: Ask the patient about other problems, including diabetes, cancer, heart disease, complications of pregnancy, psychiatric disorders, and orthopedic disorders
past medical history.medications previously prescribed: Obtain a comprehensive list of medications prescribed and/or being taken (including OTC drugs)
past medical history.other symptoms: Ask the patient about other symptoms he or she may be experiencing

social and occupational history.vocation avocation and associated repeti: What does the patient’s job require? Is the patient involved in any sports or recreational activities? Does the patient attend school?
social and occupational history.functional limitations assistance with A: Did the patient have any prior functional limitations or require any assistance with ADLs? Does the patient have any adaptive equipment? Which is the patient’s dominant hand?
social and occupational history.living environment: With whom does the patient live and who are the patient’s caregivers? Are there stairs in the home? Number of floors? Identify if there are barriers to independence in the home; any modifications necessary?

relevant tests and measures.general: While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be appropriate to ›Relevant tests and measures:  While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be appropriate to patient medical condition, functional status, and setting
relevant tests and measures.assistive and adaptive devices: Assess fit of current devices, including orthoses/splints, ADL devices, and ambulatory devices. Are they appropriate? Are they being used properly? Are other devices indicated? Does the current state of the patient’s hand(s) affect his or her ability to use assistive and ambulatory devices properly?
relevant tests and measures.balance: Assess static and dynamic balance as indicated
relevant tests and measures.circulation: Assess pulses and capillary refill time(3) –Vascular compression and insufficiency and compartment syndrome are characterized by loss of or weakened pulses, decreased capillary refill time, deep tissue pain, and paresthesia(3)Assess integrity of peripheral nerves as indicated; the median nerve is most commonly involved in upper extremity thermal or electrical burns, although ulnar and radial nerves may also be injured(23)Measure edema using circumferential or figure of eight measurements, or using water displacement (volumetric measurements)(3)Observe for proper body mechanics during functional movements; ergonomic assessment may be indicated for return to work and ADLsAssess functional mobility utilizing such objective measures as the FIM, WeeFIM (for children),(3) and Timed Up and Go (TUG) test. Mobility may be affected by the patient’s decreased ability to use hand(s)
relevant tests and measures.gait locomotion: Assess gait as indicated. Observe for abnormalities and assess safety with objective measure such as Dynamic Gait Index (DGI)Joint subluxations are common after hand burn injury, most commonly in the metacarpophalangeal (MCP) joints, resulting in a “burn claw” hand deformity. Additional deformities that are often seen following hand burns include web space contractures; flexion contractures of palm and fingers; MCP joint extension deformities; boutonniere, swan neck, and mallet deformities; and syndactyly(24)Assess coordination, fine and gross dexterity of the hand, and functional use(3) –Jebsen-Taylor  Hand Function Test –Nine-hole  peg test
relevant tests and measures.muscle strength: Assess strength of entire affected upper extremity as indicated; when appropriate, assess hand strength utilizing hand dynamometry and pinchmeter(3)Assess as appropriate for children who haven’t yet met developmental milestones
observation inspection palpation includi: Scar assessment -Modified Vancouver Scar Scale -Scores a scar in four domains: pliability, height, vascularity, and pigmentation(7) -Scar pliability can be measured with a Cutometer(7) -Pigmentation can be measured with a Mexameter(7)

-The Matching Assessment using Photographs with Scars (MAPS) scale assigns a score of 14 based on description photos for scar height, thickness, and color and texture of the scar surface(3) -Changes in scar adherence and tightness are charted and/or photographed(3)  -Are there any hand deformities developing? -A debilitating and difficult to treat deformity is the claw hand (AKA burn claw) (wrist flexion, MCP joint hyperextension, and IP joint flexion) -Other common deformities are adduction contracture of the thumb and web space contractures (e.g., burn syndactyly)

Is there hypertrophic scarring? Hypertrophic scars are raised, red, painful, pruritic, and contractile(7) -Hypertrophic scarring is the most common complication of burn injury(7) -Risk factors for hypertrophic scarring are wounds that had a prolonged inflammatory healing phase and wounds that were open for longer than 3 weeks(7)

Inspect for signs and symptoms of infection, DVT, and chronic regional pain syndrome (CRPS) (e.g., trophic changes) •Palpation:  Palpate the texture of the scar; assess for pain on palpation •Perception  (e.g., visual field, spatial relations): Assess as indicated
relevant tests and measures.range of motion: Range of motion –Assess using a goniometer and/or composite linear measurements, including distance from the tip of the finger to the distal palmar crease during finger flexion and the distance between the tip of the finger and a level surface during full -Kapandji Thumb Opposition Scale(3) -Measurement of abducted hand span(3) -Overlay tracings of the hand(3) –Contractures -Most commonly wrist extension and flexion, digit metacarpophalangeal (MP) flexion, and index finger proximal interphalangeal (PIP) flexion(2)Sum of active MCP, PIP, and DIP arc of motion in degrees of an individual digit -Burn contractures are graded based on whether they are supple and reducible or rigid and fixed, and the severity of ROM limitation(3)
relevant tests and measures.reflex testing: Assess as indicatedAssess ability to perform ADLs and self-care  activities (e.g., bathing, brushing teeth) that are very likely affected by decreased hand use. Utilize objective measures such as the Barthel Index
relevant tests and measures.sensory testing: Perform thorough sensory testing of affected areas, including vibration threshold, temperature and texture discrimination, touch threshold discrimination using two-point  discrimination and Semmes-Weinstein Monofilaments(3)
relevant tests and measures.special tests specific to diagnosis: Special tests specific to diagnosis –Disabilities of the Arm, Shoulder and Hand (DASH) Outcome Measure(3) -For additional information on the DASH, see Clinical Review…Disabilities of the Arm, Shoulder and Hand (DASH)T903177 –Michigan Hand Outcomes Questionnaire (MHQ)(3) –SF-36(3) –Burn-Specific  Health Scale–Brief  (BSHS-B)(3)
relevant tests and measures.arousal attention cognition: Assess orientation; more in-depth  testing is indicated if brain injury or other cognitive impairment is present. Utilize such measures as mini-mental  state examination (MMSE), and obtain testing done by other disciplines if possible

contraindications precautions: TENS contraindications  (9) -Presence of a cardiac demand pacemaker -Stimulation across chest -Malignancies in the area to be treated -Uncontrolled seizure disorder
TENS precautions(9) -Altered or absent sensation -Pregnancy -Protruding metal (e.g., surgical staples, external fixation) or metal implants
-Incision  stimulation should not put stress on an incision -Allergic reactions to electrodes or conduction medium, skin irritation
Therapeutic ultrasound  contraindications(9) -In an area with infection or bleeding -If a tumor is present in the area -In the area of DVT or thrombophlebitis -Over epiphyseal plates of growing bones

Therapeutic ultrasound  precautions(9) -Use caution if patient has circulatory impairments -Use caution in patients with sensory deficits and in patients who are unable to communicate sensory deficits -Use caution over plastic or metal implants -Always decrease ultrasound intensity if the patient complains of discomfort

Thermotherapy  contraindications(9) -Decreased sensation -Decreased circulation/Vascular insufficiency -Recent or potential hemorrhage -Malignancy -Acute inflammation -Infection -Where heat rubs or liniments have recently been used -In patients with cognitive deficits or if a language barrier exists
other: Always follow physician and/or surgeon orders for treatment
Utilize sterile techniques for all wound care

If any part of the extensor mechanism in the hand is disrupted, flexion of multiple joints (i.e., composite flexion), for example making a fist, is contraindicated due to the stress placed on the healing extensor mechanism

Patients with this diagnosis may be at risk for falls; follow facility protocols for fall prevention and post fall-prevention instructions at bedside, if inpatient. Ensure that patient and family/caregivers are aware of the potential for falls and educated about fall-prevention  strategies. Discharge criteria should include independence with fall-prevention strategies

Clinicians should follow the guidelines of their clinic/hospital and what is ordered by the patient’s physician. The summary below is meant to serve as a guide, not to replace orders from a physician or a clinic’s specific protocols

Only those contraindications/precautions applicable to this diagnosis are mentioned below, including with regards to modalities. Rehabilitation professionals should always use their professional judgment

assessment plan of care.diagnosis need for treatment: Patients with hand burns require rehabilitation to improve edema, wound healing, ROM, strength, coordination/dexterity, and overall function and to prevent secondary complications such as contractures and hypertrophic scarring
prognosis: The first 48 hours of burn care has the greatest impact on the morbidity and mortality of a burn victim. Early surgical intervention, wound care, enteral feeding, glucose control, metabolic management, infection control, and prevention of hypothermia and compartment syndrome all contribute to significantly lowering mortality rates and hospital length of stay(10)

Prognosis will depend upon several factors, including the extent and location of tissue damage, any associated injuries,and comorbidities and complications. Complications impacting prognosis include sepsis; gangrene (with limb amputation); and cardiac, neurologic, cognitive, or psychiatric impairments(10)
The typical healing time: superficial-thickness  burns reported to range between 3 and 10 days, superficial partial-thickness burns ~ 2weeks, and deep partial-thickness  burns ≥ 3 weeks(18)
assessment plan of care.referral to other disciplines: Referral to other disciplines Surgeon Physician  Pain management specialist Nursing for wound care needs Occupational therapy for ADL training, orthotic fabrication Psychologist or psychiatrist for depression, anxiety, or PTSD-related symptoms Physical therapy for gait training Social services for home needs Support group Speech/swallowing therapist if indicated Nutrition/dietary if indicated Appropriate authority if abuse or neglect is suspected
other considerations: Compared to burns in other regions, hand burns can be more difficult for graft fixation due to the curved and mobile surface area, which increases the risk for cicatricial contracture

The authors of a systematic review found a positive correlation between music intervention and decreased pain and anxiety and lower heart rate in burn patients; however, they cautioned that high-quality  studies are needed confirm these findings(15)
treatment summary: Typical treatment includes: –Edema management –Preservation of motion(33) –Splinting to prevent contractures and deformities(6,17,24) -Positioning in the orthosis depends upon the location of the burn and possible deformity -Dorsal burns splinted in intrinsic plus position -Palmar burns positioned with palmar extension -Circumferential burns may need to alternate between intrinsic plus and palmar extension positions -Splint is removed for ROM and wound care -Generally, a hand that is healing without complications does not have to be positioned in an orthosis unless there is a limitation in AROM of the MCP and IP joints of > 20° in extension or MCP or IP joint flexion is < 70° -Serial casting should be used to gain extension if there is < 20° of IP joint extension -For outpatients, can utilize flexion gloves, a palmar conformer, an ulnar gutter, finger gutter, or casting (usually reserved for children) -Therapists need to continually check for proper fit of the orthosis and make any necessary changes. Changes in the bulkiness of the bandages will alter the fit of the orthosis -Children can tolerate longer immobilization than adults because of the elasticity in their joints. It is important not to over-immobilize  the joints, which can result in joint stiffness, contractures, and soft tissue adhesions. As ROM and level of arousal improve, patients should increase their active participation with exercises and functional mobility(17) –PROM and then AROM exercises -Exercises are performed to help preserve joint ROM, ensure tendon gliding, and help maintain oblique and transverse retinacular ligament length(17) -If the extensor mechanism is disrupted, ROM should be performed using the tendon glide technique, mobilizing a single joint while maintaining the others in extension -Combined flexion must be avoided, as it could rupture the fragile extensor mechanism -If the burn is full thickness, the extensor mechanism in the hand is likely affected -When ROM exercises are being performed at the IP joint, the MCP joint and the wrist should be positioned in extension to put the tendon at maximum slack(17) –Scar management and prevention/management of hypertrophic scarring(4) -Risk factors for pathologic scarring (e.g., keloids, hypertrophic scar)include deep partial and full-thickness  burns (i.e., deep dermal second degree and third degree), slow healing (longer than 3 weeks), and genetic factors(16) -Scar compression (e.g., elastomer web spacers) may be helpful to decrease deformity or to maintain positioning after a contracture release(24)  -Other modalities that may be used to manage hypertrophic scarring include structural grafting (e.g., autologous fat transfer) and composite tissue allotransplantation. Evidence is weak or limited for scar massage, silicone gel sheeting, laser and light therapy, and micro needling(16) –Strengthening exercises –Functional activities

The exercise regimen and choice of orthotic intervention for exposed and ruptured tendons before grafting vary depending on the extent and location of the tendon exposure and the apparent integrity of the tendon and surrounding tissue(17) –If the tendon appears healthy and exposure is small, aggressive ROM may be ordered(17)

A case study in the United States found that 3M Coban self-adherent wraps effectively reduced edema in a patient status post skin grafting, and the reduced edema resulted in improved ROM, strength, and function compared to the other hand (control); the dressing did not impede hand mobility, grip strength, and function(11)

Nanotechnology interventions (e.g., immune-based  antimicrobial molecules, antimicrobial photo therapy and ultrasound) are showing promise in management of infection and facilitating tissue regeneration and wound healing(12)

A case study in the United Kingdom found that the technology-based wound dressing Mepitel One effectively controlled exudate, allowing for alternate-day  dressing changes. The dressing was easily removed, which reduced trauma to newly healing skin on the hand and decreased subjective complaints of pain(14)

AnRCT in Egypt found that playful activity based on games improved hand function and movement in children with hand burns better than rote exercise(13) . maintenance or prevention: Assist the patient and family with school and work reentry. If the patient is school-aged,  the patient may require a school assessment to determine if an individualized education program (IEP) is needed. If the patient is returning to work, a functional capacity exam may be required
Burn prevention counseling during routine pediatric well-visits(18)
Sun protection is essential for burn survivors(4)

Educate families about potential household hazards and prevention of burns(8) Safety in the workplace Safety in the home, including regular maintenance of smoke alarms and temperature of hot water heater –Test bathwater and supervise children during bath time; cook on rear burners when children are present Prevention of electrical burns (e.g., replace frayed cords) Sunburn prevention Appropriate supervision of small children – keep matches, lighters, and chemicals out of reach of children, fireplace safety
